questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "I am learning my lesson."'
questions.answer: She said that she was learning her lesson.
questions.explanation: In indirect speech, 'I' changes to 'she', 'am' changes to 'was', and 'my' changes to 'her'. The conjunction 'that' introduces the reported clause.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'He said to me, "I have passed the examination."'
questions.answer: He told me that he had passed the examination.
questions.explanation: 'Said to me' becomes 'told me'. Present perfect 'have passed' changes to past perfect 'had passed'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said to me, "I shall help you."'
questions.answer: She told me that she would help me.
questions.explanation: 'Shall' changes to 'would'. 'You' changes to 'me' since the person being addressed is the reporter.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "I finished my work yesterday."'
questions.answer: She said that she had finished her work the day before.
questions.explanation: Simple past 'finished' becomes past perfect 'had finished'. 'Yesterday' changes to 'the day before'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'They said, "We were watching the match."'
questions.answer: They said that they had been watching the match.
questions.explanation: Past continuous 'were watching' changes to past perfect continuous 'had been watching'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'Meera said, "I have been waiting since morning."'
questions.answer: Meera said that she had been waiting since morning.
questions.explanation: Present perfect continuous 'have been waiting' changes to past perfect continuous 'had been waiting'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said, "I may go to Delhi tomorrow."'
questions.answer: She said that she might go to Delhi the next day.
questions.explanation: 'May' changes to 'might'. 'Tomorrow' changes to 'the next day'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'The girl said, "I can do this sum."'
questions.answer: The girl said that she could do that sum.
questions.explanation: 'Can' changes to 'could'. 'This' changes to 'that' in indirect speech.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'She said to her friend, "I must work hard."'
questions.answer: She told her friend that she had to work hard.
questions.explanation: 'Must' changes to 'had to' in indirect speech when expressing necessity.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech: 'Mother said, "Children, breakfast is ready."'
questions.answer: Mother told the children that breakfast was ready.
questions.explanation: The vocative 'Children' becomes 'the children' as the object. 'Is' changes to 'was'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Imperative): 'The teacher said to the student, "Write your name."'
questions.answer: The teacher told/ordered the student to write his name.
questions.explanation: Imperatives use 'told/ordered/requested + object + to + verb'. 'Your' changes to 'his'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Imperative): 'Mother said to the child, "Don't play in the sun."'
questions.answer: Mother told/forbade the child not to play in the sun.
questions.explanation: Negative imperatives use 'not to + verb'. 'Forbade' can replace 'told...not to'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Imperative): 'He said to me, "Please lend me your book."'
questions.answer: He requested me to lend him my book.
questions.explanation: 'Please' indicates a request, so we use 'requested'. 'Your' changes to 'my', 'me' changes to 'him'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Imperative): 'The principal said to the students, "Be regular and punctual."'
questions.answer: The principal advised the students to be regular and punctual.
questions.explanation: Advice/instruction from authority uses 'advised'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Exclamatory): 'She said, "How beautiful the garden is!"'
questions.answer: She exclaimed that the garden was very beautiful.
questions.explanation: Exclamatory sentences use 'exclaimed that'. 'How beautiful' becomes 'very beautiful'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Exclamatory): 'He said, "What a wonderful match it was!"'
questions.answer: He exclaimed that it had been a wonderful match.
questions.explanation: 'What a wonderful' is expressed as 'a wonderful'. 'Was' changes to 'had been'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Exclamatory): 'She said, "Alas! I have lost my purse."'
questions.answer: She exclaimed with sorrow that she had lost her purse.
questions.explanation: 'Alas' expresses sorrow, so we use 'exclaimed with sorrow'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Exclamatory): 'He said, "Hurrah! We have won the match."'
questions.answer: He exclaimed with joy that they had won the match.
questions.explanation: 'Hurrah' expresses joy, so we use 'exclaimed with joy'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Optative): 'Mother said to me, "May God bless you!"'
questions.answer: Mother wished/prayed that God might bless me.
questions.explanation: Optative sentences (wishes/prayers) use 'wished/prayed that'. 'May' changes to 'might'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Optative): 'She said, "May you live long!"'
questions.answer: She wished that I might live long.
questions.explanation: Wishes use 'wished that'. 'You' changes to 'I' (the person addressed).

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Interrogative): 'He said to me, "Where do you live?"'
questions.answer: He asked me where I lived.
questions.explanation: Wh-questions keep the question word but change to statement word order. 'Do you live' becomes 'I lived'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Interrogative): 'She said to him, "Have you finished your work?"'
questions.answer: She asked him if/whether he had finished his work.
questions.explanation: Yes/No questions use 'if' or 'whether'. 'Have finished' becomes 'had finished'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Interrogative): 'The teacher said to the students, "Why are you late?"'
questions.answer: The teacher asked the students why they were late.
questions.explanation: 'Why' is retained. 'Are you' changes to 'they were'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Interrogative): 'Mother said to me, "Did you take your medicine?"'
questions.answer: Mother asked me if I had taken my medicine.
questions.explanation: Yes/No question in past tense: 'Did you take' becomes 'if I had taken'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Interrogative): 'He said to her, "What is your name?"'
questions.answer: He asked her what her name was.
questions.explanation: 'What' is retained. 'Is your name' becomes 'her name was'.

questions.question: Change to indirect speech (Interrogative): 'She said to me, "Will you help me?"'
questions.answer: She asked me if I would help her.
questions.explanation: 'Will' changes to 'would'. Both 'you' and 'me' change based on context.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'She told me that she was going to the market.'
questions.answer: She said to me, "I am going to the market."
questions.explanation: 'Was going' becomes 'am going'. 'She' in reported speech becomes 'I' in direct speech.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'He told his father that he had passed the examination.'
questions.answer: He said to his father, "I have passed the examination."
questions.explanation: 'Had passed' becomes 'have passed'. 'He' becomes 'I'.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'She asked me if I had seen her book.'
questions.answer: She said to me, "Have you seen my book?"
questions.explanation: 'If/whether' indicates a yes/no question. 'Had seen' becomes 'Have...seen'.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'The teacher asked the students why they were making noise.'
questions.answer: The teacher said to the students, "Why are you making noise?"
questions.explanation: 'Were making' becomes 'are making'. 'They' becomes 'you'.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'He requested me to help him.'
questions.answer: He said to me, "Please help me."
questions.explanation: 'Requested' indicates polite request, so we add 'Please'. 'Him' becomes 'me'.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'Mother told the children not to make noise.'
questions.answer: Mother said to the children, "Don't make noise."
questions.explanation: 'Not to' in indirect becomes 'Don't' in direct (negative imperative).

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'She exclaimed with joy that they had won the match.'
questions.answer: She said, "Hurrah! We have won the match."
questions.explanation: 'Exclaimed with joy' becomes 'Hurrah!' 'Had won' becomes 'have won'.

questions.question: Change to direct speech: 'He exclaimed that it was a very beautiful scene.'
questions.answer: He said, "What a beautiful scene this is!"
questions.explanation: 'Very beautiful' becomes 'What a beautiful'. 'Was' becomes 'is'.

questions.question: What is Direct Speech?
questions.answer: Direct speech is when we quote the exact words spoken by a person, enclosed in quotation marks. For example: She said, "I am going to school."
questions.explanation: In direct speech, the actual words of the speaker are reproduced exactly as they were spoken.

questions.question: What is Indirect Speech (Reported Speech)?
questions.answer: Indirect speech is when we report what someone said without using their exact words. The meaning is preserved but the words and tenses change. For example: She said that she was going to school.
questions.explanation: In indirect speech, we report the substance of what was said, not the exact words.

questions.question: What are the main changes when converting direct speech to indirect speech?
questions.answer: The main changes are: 1) Remove quotation marks and add 'that' (for statements), 2) Change pronouns appropriately (I to he/she, you to I/him/her, etc.), 3) Change tenses (present to past, past to past perfect), 4) Change time/place words (today to that day, here to there, etc.).
questions.explanation: These changes ensure the reported speech correctly reflects the perspective of the reporter.

questions.question: How do tenses change from direct to indirect speech?
questions.answer: Simple present becomes simple past, present continuous becomes past continuous, present perfect becomes past perfect, simple past becomes past perfect, 'will' becomes 'would', 'can' becomes 'could', 'may' becomes 'might'.
questions.explanation: This 'backshift' of tenses occurs because we are reporting something that was said in the past.

questions.question: How are imperative sentences changed to indirect speech?
questions.answer: Imperative sentences use reporting verbs like 'told', 'ordered', 'requested', 'advised', followed by object + to + infinitive. Negative imperatives use 'not to + infinitive'. Example: "Close the door." becomes 'He told me to close the door.'
questions.explanation: The choice of reporting verb depends on the tone - 'ordered' for commands, 'requested' for polite requests, 'advised' for suggestions.

questions.question: How are interrogative sentences changed to indirect speech?
questions.answer: For yes/no questions, use 'if' or 'whether'. For wh-questions, retain the question word. Change to statement word order (subject before verb). Example: "Are you coming?" becomes 'He asked if I was coming.'
questions.explanation: The question mark is removed in indirect speech and the sentence becomes a statement.
